ScrollingActivity
"Material is the metaphor.

"
"A material metaphor is the unifying theory of a rationalized space and a system of motion." "The material is grounded in tactile reality, inspired by the study of paper and ink, yet " "technologically advanced and open to imagination and magic.
" "Surfaces and edges of the material provide visual cues that are grounded in reality. The " "use of familiar tactile attributes helps users quickly understand affordances. Yet the " "flexibility of the material creates new affordances that supercede those in the physical " "world, without breaking the rules of physics.
" "The fundamentals of light, surface, and movement are key to conveying how objects move, " "interact, and exist in space and in relation to each other. Realistic lighting shows " "seams, divides space, and indicates moving parts.

"
"Bold, graphic, intentional.

"
"The foundational elements of print based design typography, grids, space, scale, color, " "and use of imagery guide visual treatments. These elements do far more than please the " "eye. They create hierarchy, meaning, and focus. Deliberate color choices, edge to edge " "imagery, large scale typography, and intentional white space create a bold and graphic " "interface that immerse the user in the experience.
" "An emphasis on user actions makes core functionality immediately apparent and provides " "waypoints for the user.

"
"Motion provides meaning.

"
"Motion respects and reinforces the user as the prime mover. Primary user actions are " "inflection points that initiate motion, transforming the whole design.
" "All action takes place in a single environment. Objects are presented to the user without " "breaking the continuity of experience even as they transform and reorganize.
" "Motion is meaningful and appropriate, serving to focus attention and maintain continuity. " "Feedback is subtle yet clear. Transitions are efﬁcient yet coherent.

"
"3D world.

"
"The material environment is a 3D space, which means all objects have x, y, and z " "dimensions. The z-axis is perpendicularly aligned to the plane of the display, with the " "positive z-axis extending towards the viewer. Every sheet of material occupies a single " "position along the z-axis and has a standard 1dp thickness.
" "On the web, the z-axis is used for layering and not for perspective. The 3D world is " "emulated by manipulating the y-axis.

"
"Light and shadow.

"
"Within the material environment, virtual lights illuminate the scene. Key lights create " "directional shadows, while ambient light creates soft shadows from all angles.
" "Shadows in the material environment are cast by these two light sources. In Android " "development, shadows occur when light sources are blocked by sheets of material at " "various positions along the z-axis. On the web, shadows are depicted by manipulating the " "y-axis only. The following example shows the card with a height of 6dp.

"
"Resting elevation.

"
"All material objects, regardless of size, have a resting elevation, or default elevation " "that does not change. If an object changes elevation, it should return to its resting " "elevation as soon as possible.

"
"Component elevations.

"
"The resting elevation for a component type is consistent across apps (e.g., FAB elevation " "does not vary from 6dp in one app to 16dp in another app).
" "Components may have different resting elevations across platforms, depending on the depth " "of the environment (e.g., TV has a greater depth than mobile or desktop).

"
"Responsive elevation and dynamic elevation offsets.

"
"Some component types have responsive elevation, meaning they change elevation in response " "to user input (e.g., normal, focused, and pressed) or system events. These elevation " "changes are consistently implemented using dynamic elevation offsets.
" "Dynamic elevation offsets are the goal elevation that a component moves towards, relative " "to the component’s resting state. They ensure that elevation changes are consistent " "across actions and component types. For example, all components that lift on press have " "the same elevation change relative to their resting elevation.
" "Once the input event is completed or cancelled, the component will return to its resting " "elevation.

"
"Avoiding elevation interference.

"
"Components with responsive elevations may encounter other components as they move between " "their resting elevations and dynamic elevation offsets. Because material cannot pass " "through other material, components avoid interfering with one another any number of ways, " "whether on a per component basis or using the entire app layout.
" "On a component level, components can move or be removed before they cause interference. " "For example, a floating action button (FAB) can disappear or move off screen before a " "user picks up a card, or it can move if a snackbar appears.
" "On the layout level, design your app layout to minimize opportunities for interference. " "For example, position the FAB to one side of stream of a cards so the FAB won’t interfere " "when a user tries to pick up one of cards.

"
PreviewWorkout StartWorkout enter_sets LogSets Step 1: Sit down, elbows should be at 90-degrees triceps should be parallel with the ground and palms should be facing the body.
Step 2: Keeping the 90-degree angle and triceps parallel, contract the upper back and turn the wrists so that the hands are in line with the torso.
Step 3: From this position lift the dumbbells by fully extend the arms. 
Tips: Keep a neutral back. Step 1: Stand under the bar resting the barbell on the trapezius muscle and stick out the butt slightly. 
Step 2: With an upright chest squat down. 
Tips: Do not allow the knees to go past the toes. Do not allow the knees to cave in. Keep your weight back in your heels. Step 1: Lay down with the back against the bench. Keep the chest up with the shoulder blades squeezed together. 
Step 2: Unrack the weight keeping tight form and lower the barbell to the bottom position keeping elbows in and lats tight. 
Tips: Do not let the elbows flare out. Wider grips heavily target the chest muscles. Narrow grips heavily target the triceps. Step 1: Stand up with chest upright and shoulder blades retracted. Keep the chest up with the shoulder blades squeezed together. 
Step 2: Keeping the elbows close to the body, contract the biceps and lift the weight to the top position. 
Tips: Do not round shoulders. Hold the contraction for a 1-second pause at the top. Step 1: Approach the bar with a should-width stance then bend down and grab the bar with a pronated grip. Keep the chest up, hips should be back and the knees should be bent. 
Step 2: Driving through the heels pull the weight to the top position. The spine should stay neutral throughout the movement. Also, the bar should stay close to the body. 
Tips: Do not jerk the weight. Do not let the shoulders round. Squeeze the glutes for a 1-second contraction at the top position. Step 1: Stand under the bar resting the barbell on the shoulders with butt slightly back. Bring the arms up at a 90 degrees so that the elbows are parallel with the ground. Now, cross the arms so that the hands are touching the opposite shoulders and touching the bar. 
Step 2: With an upright chest squat down. 
Tips: Do not allow the knees to go past the toes. Do not allow the knees to cave in. Keep your weight back in your heels. Step 1: Stand holding the bar in the hands with an upright chest and feet shoulder width apart.
Step 2: Keeping an upright chest and neutral spine. Bend over keeping your butt back and legs straight. 
Tips: Bring the bar down to about the shins. Keep your weight back in your heels. Keep the bar close body. Step 1: Lay down with the back against the bench. Keep the chest up with the shoulder blades squeezed together. 
Step 2: Unrack the weight keeping tight form and lower the barbell to the bottom position keeping elbows in and lats tight. 
Tips: Do not let the elbows flare out. Narrow grips heavily target the triceps. Step 1: Sitting down select one arm and rest it against the same side leg with the tricep against mid-thigh. 
Step 2: From this position lift the dumbbell concentrating on the bicep contraction throughout the movement. When finished switch to other arm.
Tips: Keep back neutral. Off-hand can be used to spot. Hold the contraction for a 1-second pause at the top. Step 1: Place arms on Lean forward until the back is parallel with the ground. The hips should be back with the knees slightly bent. The partner should be used as weight and sit on your hips.
Step 2: From this position, using the balls of the feet push against the ground contracting the calves until the calf muscles are fully contracted.
Tips: Hold the contraction for a 1-second pause at the top position. Use heavier people to increase difficulty. Step 1: Lay down with the back against the bench. Keep the chest up with the shoulder blades squeezed together. 
Step 2: From the top position keeping the biceps and chest engaged, stretch the chest by spreading the arms and then contract the chest returning to the top position. 
Tips: Both forearms should be parallel with each. The forearms should remain perpendicular to the ground. Step 1: Stand with an upright torso keeping a neutral spine. 
Step 2: Using a pronated grip with the hands facing behind, keep arms fully extended and raise the arms forward until they are parallel with the ground. 
Tips: Keep a neutral back. Lighter weights are appropriate for this exercise. Step 1: Stand with an upright torso keeping a neutral spine.
Step 2: Using a pronated grip with the hands facing the thighs, keep arms extended with a slight bend and raise the arms until they are parallel with the ground.
Tips: Keep a neutral back. Lighter weights are appropriate for this exercise. Step 1: Stand with an upright torso keeping a neutral spine.
Step 2: Holding the dumbbells with the hands, begin shrugging the shoulders.
Tips: Keep a neutral back. Heavier weights can be used for this exercise. Step 1: Stand up with chest upright and shoulder blades retracted. Keep the chest up with the shoulder blades squeezed together.
Step 2: Turn hands so that palms are facing the legs at the bottom position. Keeping wrists neutral contract the biceps and lift the weight to the top position. 
Tips: Do not round shoulders. Hold the contraction for a 1-second pause at the top. Step 1: Lay down with the back against the bench. Keep the chest up with the shoulder blades squeezed together. 
Step 2: From the top position, keeping tight form, lower the weight keeping elbows in and lats tight. 
Tips: Do not let the elbows flare out. Step 1: Sit down with an upright torso reach up and grab the bar using a pronated grip. 
Step 2: Using the lats, begin pulling the bar towards the upper chest. A slight backward lean is acceptable. 
Tips: Either a wide or narrow grip may be used. Hold the contraction for a 1-second pause. Step 1: Adjust the chair and/or the pad so that the pad is resting a few inches below the calves. Legs should be extended.
Step 2: Contract the hamstrings bringing the legs to a 90-degree angle.
Tips: Hold the contraction for a 1-second pause at the bottom. Step 1: Adjust the chair and/or the pad so that the pad is resting on the shins. The knees should be at a 90-degree angle
Step 2: Extend the legs fully contracting the quadriceps.
Tips: Hold the contraction for a 1-second pause at the top. Step 1: Sitting down select one arm and rest the tricep against the pad.
Step 2: From this position lift the dumbbell concentrating on the bicep contraction throughout the movement. When finished switch to other arm.
Tips: Keep back neutral. Off-hand can be used to spot. Hold the contraction for a 1-second pause at the top. Step 1: Lay down with the chest against the bench. Keep the shoulder rounded.
Step 2: From the bottom position keeping the biceps and upper back engaged, pull the arms away from each other raising the weight to the top position.
Tips: Hold the contraction for a 1-second pause at the top. Step 1: Start with chest up and butt slightly back with a slight bend in the knee. The rope should be level with upper abdominals.
Step 2: Keeping tight form pull down on the rope contracting the triceps.
Tips: Do not flare out elbows. Hold the contraction for a 1-second pause at the bottom. Step 1: Sit down with an upright torso. The shoulder blades should remain retracted throughout the movement. Knees should be bent slightly with the feet pressed against the platform.
Step 2: With a flat back, pull the weight towards the middle abdominal region with the lats(bellybutton).
Tips: Do not jerk the weight. Do not let the shoulders round Hold the contraction for a 1-second pause at the back position. Step 1: Sit down with the balls of the feet against the platform.
Step 2: Driving through the heels pull the weight to the top position. The spine should stay neutral throughout the movement. Also, the bar should stay close to the body.
Tips: Do not jerk the weight. Do not let the shoulders round. Squeeze the glutes for a 1-second contraction at the top position. Step 1: Sit down holding the barbell at just under chin level. Grip should be wide enough so that the forearms are perpendicular to the bar.
Step 2: From this position fully extend the arms lifting the bar vertically.
Tips: Keep a neutral back. Step 1: Using a wide stance reach down and grab the bar. Knees should be slightly bent with the hips back.
Step 2: With a flat back, pull the weight towards the upper abdominal region.
Tips: Do not jerk the weight. Do not let the shoulders round Hold the contraction for a 1-second pause at the top position. Step 1: Start with weight in hand and arms raised above the head. Palms should be facing forward as opposed to backward.
Step 2: Keeping the upper arms close to the head bend at the elbow lowering the weight behind you. The elbows will come out slightly and move forward.
Tips: Keep back straight. Do not flare out elbows. Step 1: Lay down with the back against the ground and knees bent with the heels flat on the ground. Rest the barbell directly above the hips.
Step 2: Driving through the heels, extend the hips vertically through the bar. The upper back should remain on the ground.
Tips: Focus on generating strong contractions in the glutes throughout the movement. Step 1: Reach up and grab the pullup bar with two hands. Both hands should be facing the same way.
Step 2: Using the lats, begin pulling the upper chest towards the bar. A slight backward lean is acceptable.
Tips: Either a wide or narrow grip may be used. Hold the contraction for a 1-second pause at the top position. Step 1: Start in the top upright position with arms nearly locked.
Step 2: From the top position staying tight keeping a straight back, lower yourself using the triceps until the arms are at a 90-degree angle.
Step 3: Contracting the triceps push against the bars to return to the top position.
Tips: Do not flare out elbows.
